recommendations: Matt Javit ‚ÄúIt's hard to imagine that better leadership could exist for a $B+ unit than Raj Nath. With extraordinary intellect and social IQ, savviness with an unbelievable ability to adjust in the moment, and a genuinely humble approach with all parts of the organization, he is a CEO who walks the walks, always delivering to his commitments. His kind, thoughtful demeanor is calming in the most anxious of times and appreciated by all that work with him. Having Raj lead the final stages of a particular multiyear, multimillion-dollar deal, gave me the chance to work alongside him as we built out the global delivery model, leveraged the national sales organization, and negotiated with the client. I've never enjoyed working harder for someone than I did for Raj Nath, and I am grateful I had the opportunity. ‚Äù

I am grateful for all the support and leadership he has provided.‚Äù

detailed_profile.name: Joe Morris
detailed_profile.position: Global Digital Marketing Leader | Content, Branding, Connection | ex-Capgemini
detailed_profile.about: I‚Äôm a digital and content strategy leader with a decade of experience building global programs that connect brands with people in meaningful ways. At Capgemini, I led the global social media and advocacy function‚Äîshaping content across 180+ channels, launching new storytelling formats like podcasts and video, and building an employee advocacy program used by 340,000 people. I also developed global governance frameworks, authored social media guidelines, and led a distributed team of content and digital professionals across regions. Alongside that, I managed paid media budgets of $1M+ and created executive visibility programs, helping our CEO become a LinkedIn Top Voice. What ties it all together is my belief in thoughtful, purposeful communication. Whether I‚Äôm devising strategy, writing copy, or leading a team, I care most about content that‚Äôs authentic, clear, and useful to the audience. I‚Äôm especially motivated by work that helps organizations show up with integrity‚Äîand that builds real trust with their audiences. Expert in: ‚Ä¢ Content & Editorial Strategy ‚Ä¢ Social Media & Employee Advocacy ‚Ä¢ Digital Campaigns & Paid Media ‚Ä¢ Executive Visibility & Thought Leadership ‚Ä¢ Governance, Enablement & Team Leadership Outside of work, you‚Äôll usually find me listening to (or playing) music, cooking something my children don‚Äôt want to eat, or watching TV shows about terrible things happening to people. Let‚Äôs connect.

publications.title: Inbound freight consolidation: a simulation model to evaluate consolidation rules
publications.subtitle: Thesis (M. Eng. in Logistics)--Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Engineering Systems Division, 2006.
publications.description: In logistics, freight can be consolidated over time (temporally) or over space (spatially). This thesis presents a simulation model to evaluate temporal and spatial consolidation rules. The model is the result of a research project to analyze freight consolidation options for a large industrial company. The research project focused on the company's freight imported from China to the US, and the model presented in the thesis is structured to represent a typical import logistics network. The results section of the thesis presents a method for evaluating consolidation rules. The results recommend temporal consolidation of two weeks at the origin port and temporal consolidation of less than one week at the factory for the company's shipments from China to the US. This consolidation policy offers total network cost savings of 24% over the base case, an immediate ship policy.

recommendations: Peter A. Schwartz ‚ÄúThe most effective global marketing leaders have one eye fixed on the horizon and the other on their organization‚Äôs current position. They are problem-finders and problem-solvers. And for their clients, they continually seek new ways to create value and new value to create. In my experience working with Heather, I found her to be a highly creative, growth-oriented market strategist. She was able to put herself in the shoes‚Äîand even the minds‚Äîof her firm‚Äôs clients, prospects, and competitors. She also made a point of understanding the complex social systems at play in her work environment and provided her global teams with the context, purpose, and values to encourage their best efforts and support their professional development. Perhaps most important, people who work with and for Heather feel noticed, included, and appreciated.‚Äù

Barbara Chai ‚ÄúHeather inspires the strongest loyalty from her team members in a remarkable way. She balances candor with compassion when communicating with her team, and is a fierce advocate for her people when communicating outside of her team. Even long after she has finished serving in a role, she continues to check in on her former team members to ask how they‚Äôre doing, provide a gut check or offer to help in any way. She is passionate about her work and her people, and takes great pride in mentoring and nurturing younger colleagues. As a peer, Heather is supportive, generous and collaborative. When she sees good work, even when done by other teams, she props it up and shines a spotlight on all the people who contributed to it. She is always learning in addition to teaching. She is a mentor to a wide range of people and generously offers her time and guidance when asked. It is this quality that truly distinguishes Heather as a leader. She is also a master at her craft. Her communication style is confident and sharp. Her strategies are data-informed, experience-driven and multi-layered. She is a creative, analytical and persuasive storyteller. Her ability to see and describe the picture from miles above in the sky, and from underneath a canopy of trees, is inspiring. Above all, Heather is a very kind and thoughtful person. She is a rare talent and any organization would be lucky to have her as a leader.‚Äù

organizations.title: Girls Who Code
organizations.description: Girls Who Code is a nonprofit organization which aims to support and increase the number of women in computer science. The organization is working to close the gender employment difference in technology and change the image of what a programmer looks like. The aim is to inspire, educate, and equip young women with the computing skills to pursue 21st century opportunities.

current_company.name: Capgemini
current_company.title: Executive Vice President - Data Driven Business & GenAI

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: As the Executive Vice President of Data Driven Business and Generative AI (GenAI) at Capgemini, I lead the strategic transformation towards integrating AI across business operations. My mission is to prepare companies for a future dominated by AI, ensuring they harness these technologies to stay ahead in their industries. I focus on embedding AI seamlessly into business processes, redesigning KPI frameworks to effectively measure AI performance, and evolving the data culture to empower data-driven decision-making. My role involves updating Capgemini's service offerings to align with the cutting-edge demands of GenAI, working closely with industry leaders in retail, telecommunications, banking, insurance, and manufacturing to tailor AI strategies that offer a competitive advantage.A key part of my work is developing industry-specific models that outline the future state of business in an AI-driven world, guiding companies on integrating digital employees and ensuring ethical, responsible AI use. My goal is to transform businesses into agile, AI-empowered entities, ready to thrive in the digital era.
positions.title: Executive Vice President - Data Driven Business & GenAI
positions.description_html:
As the Executive Vice President of Data Driven Business and Generative AI (GenAI) at Capgemini, I lead the strategic transformation towards integrating AI across business operations. My mission is to prepare companies for a future dominated by AI, ensuring they harness these technologies to stay ahead in their industries.

I focus on embedding AI seamlessly into business processes, redesigning KPI frameworks to effectively measure AI performance, and evolving the data culture to empower data-driven decision-making. My role involves updating Capgemini's service offerings to align with the cutting-edge demands of GenAI, working closely with industry leaders in retail, telecommunications, banking, insurance, and manufacturing to tailor AI strategies that offer a competitive advantage.

A key part of my work is developing industry-specific models that outline the future state of business in an AI-driven world, guiding companies on integrating digital employees and ensuring ethical, responsible AI use. My goal is to transform businesses into agile, AI-empowered entities, ready to thrive in the digital era.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: Data has gone from being the passenger in IT estates, to being the primary driver of new business value across organizations. In this role I work across the Capgemini business is how our services become data driven and what it will take to truly transform our clients into fully data driven enterprises. Understanding how AI is transforming Cyber defense, how automation is moving from 'screens' to outcomes and building the next generation of solutions where data and AI drive. The role was created specifically to ensure that data is not a single practice within Capgemini but becomes something systemic across our business, and the business of our clients.Part of the role includes how AI Trust will be defined and managed, ensuring that AI is executed in line with the business objectives, ethical concerns and regulatory constraints the organization requires.
positions.title: Executive Vice President - Collaborative Data Ecosystems
positions.description_html:
Data has gone from being the passenger in IT estates, to being the primary driver of new business value across organizations. In this role I work across the Capgemini business is how our services become data driven and what it will take to truly transform our clients into fully data driven enterprises. Understanding how AI is transforming Cyber defense, how automation is moving from 'screens' to outcomes and building the next generation of solutions where data and AI drive. The role was created specifically to ensure that data is not a single practice within Capgemini but becomes something systemic across our business, and the business of our clients.

Part of the role includes how AI Trust will be defined and managed, ensuring that AI is executed in line with the business objectives, ethical concerns and regulatory constraints the organization requires.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: With AI taking control of more business functions the challenge of trusting AI is increasing. My role is to work across our group, from people creating manufacturing robots and using AI in drug discovery, through to marketing communications to ensure that the AIs that are created are trusted. Trust means accountability of the AI, which means the team creating it ensures there is a clear owner, that its boundaries are clearly identified and the business, regulatory and ethical concerns are met.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: Responsible for Capgemini's North American Insights and Data business. The Insights and Data (I&D) practice is a full service global business line within Capgemini that covers the full information lifecycle from data ingestion and access, through management, governance and strategy to data science and advanced AI. My role as the leader of the North American practice is to deliver double digit growth and create an organisation capable of addressing some of the most complex information challenges in the market today. The team works across all sectors, outside of financial services, in North America and represents several thousand people working for our clients today.In a 12 month turn around focus I led the team to an over 20% absolute improvement in growth and reduced attrition by over 5%.
positions.title: Head of Insights & Data, Capgemini North America
positions.description_html:
Responsible for Capgemini's North American Insights and Data business. The Insights and Data (I&D) practice is a full service global business line within Capgemini that covers the full information lifecycle from data ingestion and access, through management, governance and strategy to data science and advanced AI. My role as the leader of the North American practice is to deliver double digit growth and create an organisation capable of addressing some of the most complex information challenges in the market today. The team works across all sectors, outside of financial services, in North America and represents several thousand people working for our clients today.

In a 12 month turn around focus I led the team to an over 20% absolute improvement in growth and reduced attrition by over 5%.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: Responsible for Capgemini's global AI Engineering division a team of over 3,000 engineers focused on creating the next generation Big Data platforms and industrialised approaches that enable business to much more quickly adopt AI technologies and concentrate on the value that they want to deliver.Capgemini's approach to AI Engineering is to focus on the standardisation and industrialisation of the major challenge of AI - getting the data in, ensure the data is correct and then ensuring the insight is delivered to the right end-point. This includes:- AI platform provisioning and management- Industrialized ingestion- DevOps and DevOps 4 Data- Migration to Big Data services- Automation of testing, reconciliation and other non-functional elements- Real-time eventing and integrationA core part of Capgemini's approach to AI engineering is the shift away from traditional BI delivery models towards new digital centric approaches based on business service architectures, microservices and automated through the use of Dev Ops. Helping customers not simply to transform their data landscape but also transform the way they deliver data projects.
positions.title: Global VP AI Engineering and Digital Delivery
positions.description_html:
Responsible for Capgemini's global AI Engineering division a team of over 3,000 engineers focused on creating the next generation Big Data platforms and industrialised approaches that enable business to much more quickly adopt AI technologies and concentrate on the value that they want to deliver.

Capgemini's approach to AI Engineering is to focus on the standardisation and industrialisation of the major challenge of AI - getting the data in, ensure the data is correct and then ensuring the insight is delivered to the right end-point. This includes:
- AI platform provisioning and management
- Industrialized ingestion
- DevOps and DevOps 4 Data
- Migration to Big Data services
- Automation of testing, reconciliation and other non-functional elements
- Real-time eventing and integration

A core part of Capgemini's approach to AI engineering is the shift away from traditional BI delivery models towards new digital centric approaches based on business service architectures, microservices and automated through the use of Dev Ops. Helping customers not simply to transform their data landscape but also transform the way they deliver data projects.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: Responsible for the leadership, transformation and management of Capgemini's Big Data business from multiple regional teams into a single global organisation that has more than tripled its sales rate in the first two years. Moving from regional teams to a global team covering all sectors and with over 2,000 dedicated Big Data specialists in the Americas, Europe, India and Asia Pacific the business has been a major pull-through of work for other areas of the firm by taking an "Industrialised First" approach to delivering Big Data programs.Key to the approach of both growing the business but also delivering continued and sustained client success has been the ability to leverage global perspectives for local business problems. This comes from having a unified approach to Big Data and Data Science solution architecture and providing proven and consistent ways of not just delivering analytical value but reducing operational costs over traditional data solutions.
positions.title: Global Vice President - Big Data
positions.description_html:
Responsible for the leadership, transformation and management of Capgemini's Big Data business from multiple regional teams into a single global organisation that has more than tripled its sales rate in the first two years. Moving from regional teams to a global team covering all sectors and with over 2,000 dedicated Big Data specialists in the Americas, Europe, India and Asia Pacific the business has been a major pull-through of work for other areas of the firm by taking an "Industrialised First" approach to delivering Big Data programs.

Key to the approach of both growing the business but also delivering continued and sustained client success has been the ability to leverage global perspectives for local business problems. This comes from having a unified approach to Big Data and Data Science solution architecture and providing proven and consistent ways of not just delivering analytical value but reducing operational costs over traditional data solutions.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini

positions.subtitle: Global Outsourcing, Capgemini
positions.description: Originally Head of SOA for Capgemini's Global Outsourcing division I took over the SaaS role as part of the Google partnership. Focus is on the strategic direction of SOA and SaaS for customers and outsourcers and how it can be used to align IT spend more closely to the business value it provides.During this time I defined the group approach towards the SaaS and Cloud markets and created the foundations for the group's transition towards these new technology areas. Working with Amazon, Salesforce.com on the cloud/SaaS area and traditional vendors such as Microsoft, Oracle, IBM and SAP on how their technologies could be licensed and supported in these new environments.Another key part of the role was the strategy for Application Outsourcing where I worked on how SOA, SaaS and other elements were changing Application Outsourcing and defined a new joined up approach between Application Run/Operations and Application Development. At the time the group had two separate divisions for Run and Development and this work provided a framework that enabled the two to be considered as a continuum. The group moved to a unified management structure a couple of years after this work completed.
positions.title: Head of SOA and SaaS
positions.description_html:
Originally Head of SOA for Capgemini's Global Outsourcing division I took over the SaaS role as part of the Google partnership. Focus is on the strategic direction of SOA and SaaS for customers and outsourcers and how it can be used to align IT spend more closely to the business value it provides.

During this time I defined the group approach towards the SaaS and Cloud markets and created the foundations for the group's transition towards these new technology areas. Working with Amazon, Salesforce.com on the cloud/SaaS area and traditional vendors such as Microsoft, Oracle, IBM and SAP on how their technologies could be licensed and supported in these new environments.

Another key part of the role was the strategy for Application Outsourcing where I worked on how SOA, SaaS and other elements were changing Application Outsourcing and defined a new joined up approach between Application Run/Operations and Application Development. At the time the group had two separate divisions for Run and Development and this work provided a framework that enabled the two to be considered as a continuum. The group moved to a unified management structure a couple of years after this work completed.

publications.title: Sea Change - is your company prepared for the coming big data wave?
publications.subtitle: Teradata
publications.description: Every business leader knows that in today‚Äôs knowledge economy, it is essential to take control of information to make decisions with confidence. The challenge is to quickly identify what should be retained, avoid duplication where possible, and make use of the insights being generated.

publications.title: Mastering Big Data
publications.subtitle: Capgemini
publications.description: The amount of data being created by organizations is increasing exponentially every year and is not something that companies can opt out of. The challenge is therefore to quickly identify what should be retained, avoid duplication where possible, and make use of the information that is being generated. Big Data is not about acquiring data from outside of an organization; it‚Äôs about combining the Big Data being created internally with external Big Data sets.Big Data is, therefore, about being able to access and leverage much larger information sets than ever before in order to gain greater insight into markets and opportunities. At the heart of Big Data is the ability to ask questions about what will happen and receive more accurate answers than has been possible until now.

publications.title: Mastering Retail
publications.subtitle: Capgemini
publications.description: Retail is a competitive business and in the modern world the effective exploitation of information is a critical factor for business success. However, despite the fact that the retail sector pioneered the concept of mastering and controlling key pieces of business information, in many areas of the industry vital information remains beyond the control of the business.

publications.title: Building the Business Case for Master Data Management
publications.subtitle: Capgemini
publications.description: An effective business case for master data management (MDM) communicates the problem of fragmented and contradictory data in terms that are relevant to business decision-makers.Much like master data itself, an MDM business case is ideally complete, reliable and timely. This white paper outlines the key considerations that IT professionals should keep in mind when formulating an MDM business case.

publications.title: Mastering Social Media
publications.subtitle: Capgemini
publications.description: Social media is the current buzzword in marketing and IT, and generating a significant amount of both interest and hot-air. The reality is that social media does not represent a revolution in marketing or customer engagement but it does represent a significant evolution, and one that presents businesses with greater opportunities. In order to really leverage social media, organizations need to stop looking at it as a separate world and look at how the normal processes of customer identification and acquisition can be extended to incorporate the social world.Treating social media as another enterprise information asset and incorporating it into the overall enterprise information map will deliver the benefits expected from social media marketing but even more so, will enable the collaboration of physical, electronic and social marketing, and provide risk and servicing areas with better information on the customer and how they behave.

publications.title: Mastering the Information Ocean
publications.subtitle: Capgemini
publications.description: In the modern business, the volume of information is increasing and the value of that information is becoming ever more critical to the business‚Äôs success. The reality though is that over 80% of companies are relying on inaccurate management reports and that most organizations find themselves drowning in data. Although there are a large number of different challenges in turning data into information, there is one common element which drives problems in one third of customer service interactions, 30% of brokerage transactions and which drives up to $50bn in costs within the US retail supply chain alone ‚Äì poor Master Data Management.

publications.title: Enterprise SOA Adoption Strategies
publications.subtitle: InfoQ
publications.description: Major changes in technology have not been driven by the technologies themselves but by the change in thinking that they enabled. OO design changed software by changing thoughts away from procedures and onto real world "things". This book argues that for SOA to succeed we must move our thoughts away from the implementation technologies and towards the "what" of the business. Using a straight-forward, pictorially driven, methodology the book explains who to discover what the business services really are and how to construct an overall business service architecture. The book covers defining the Business Service Architecture, how to classify services for business value and delivery, understanding the role of IT in supporting the architecture, how project and portfolio management needs to change, how to use a Service Architecture to identify KPIs, and how and when to use Business Process in a service architecture.

publications.title: Toward an Acceptable Definition of Service
publications.subtitle: IEEE Software
publications.description: The methodologies such as extreme programming and the Rational Unified Process claim that they work with service-oriented architecture, but neither was designed with SOA in mind. Both predominately focuses on a project's delivery, not on the system's initial conceptualization. For service definition to succeed, there must be tooled support for the automatic flow of information among architects, designers, developers, maintainers, and, most importantly, the client. XML and Web service standards are helping architects improve the definition of service and provide a consistent framework for realizing service-oriented architecture's promises.

publications.title: Next Generation Airline Information: Using Consumer Devices to Keep Passengers Informed and as an Additional Channel to Market
publications.subtitle: IEEE
publications.description: The airline industries are going through a period of change and face many challenges to keep consumers loyal to their services and to offer differential services with low production cost. The rise of J2ME mobile phones presents an opportunity and a challenge to airline companies, the chance to increase information available to passengers to reduce dissatisfaction, and the challenge of how to produce applications for a wide variety of devices. It also enables companies to offer additional services via an application that is resident on the consumer?s own phone. Using the security and storage options available on J2ME devices, airlines, and other companies, can use mobile phones as a mechanism to enable "least resistance" selling. This paper details how one prototyping exercise demonstrated how J2ME mobile phones, both on the original MIDP 1.0 and the more advanced MIDP 2.0 offered a clear business and cost advantage to one UK based airline. Hopefully by the time this paper is read the prototypes will be functioning systems that are being used by consumers.

basic_info.name: Shashi Gupta
basic_info.search_snippet: As the VP and Global Head for AWS CoE at Capgemini Financial Services, I enable AWS solutions across banking, capital markets, and insurance domains.

detailed_profile.name: Shashi Gupta
detailed_profile.city: East Brunswick, New Jersey, United States
detailed_profile.position: VP and Global Head AWS CoE - Capgemini Financial Services
detailed_profile.about: With over 21 years of experience in the IT industry, I am a passionate and visionary leader in cloud strategy and solutions for the financial services sector. As the VP and Global Head for AWS CoE at Capgemini Financial Services, I enable AWS solutions across banking, capital markets, and insurance domains, leveraging my AWS certification and expertise. I also lead the global eAPM and AWS DevOps solutions, delivering innovative and agile solutions that enhance customer experience, operational efficiency, and business value. Previously, I held various roles at Capgemini, such as delivery partner, transformation head, senior delivery and client engagement manager, and QA test engineer, where I gained extensive skills in business analysis, test management, and DevOps. I am driven by the mission of empowering our clients and teams to achieve excellence and sustainability in the digital era. I bring diverse perspectives and experiences to the table. I am always eager to learn new technologies, collaborate with stakeholders, and contribute to the growth and success of Capgemini and its customers.

current_company.name: Capgemini
current_company.title: Executive Vice President - Data Driven Business & GenAI

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: As the Executive Vice President of Data Driven Business and Generative AI (GenAI) at Capgemini, I lead the strategic transformation towards integrating AI across business operations. My mission is to prepare companies for a future dominated by AI, ensuring they harness these technologies to stay ahead in their industries. I focus on embedding AI seamlessly into business processes, redesigning KPI frameworks to effectively measure AI performance, and evolving the data culture to empower data-driven decision-making. My role involves updating Capgemini's service offerings to align with the cutting-edge demands of GenAI, working closely with industry leaders in retail, telecommunications, banking, insurance, and manufacturing to tailor AI strategies that offer a competitive advantage.A key part of my work is developing industry-specific models that outline the future state of business in an AI-driven world, guiding companies on integrating digital employees and ensuring ethical, responsible AI use. My goal is to transform businesses into agile, AI-empowered entities, ready to thrive in the digital era.
positions.title: Executive Vice President - Data Driven Business & GenAI
positions.description_html:
As the Executive Vice President of Data Driven Business and Generative AI (GenAI) at Capgemini, I lead the strategic transformation towards integrating AI across business operations. My mission is to prepare companies for a future dominated by AI, ensuring they harness these technologies to stay ahead in their industries.

I focus on embedding AI seamlessly into business processes, redesigning KPI frameworks to effectively measure AI performance, and evolving the data culture to empower data-driven decision-making. My role involves updating Capgemini's service offerings to align with the cutting-edge demands of GenAI, working closely with industry leaders in retail, telecommunications, banking, insurance, and manufacturing to tailor AI strategies that offer a competitive advantage.

A key part of my work is developing industry-specific models that outline the future state of business in an AI-driven world, guiding companies on integrating digital employees and ensuring ethical, responsible AI use. My goal is to transform businesses into agile, AI-empowered entities, ready to thrive in the digital era.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: Data has gone from being the passenger in IT estates, to being the primary driver of new business value across organizations. In this role I work across the Capgemini business is how our services become data driven and what it will take to truly transform our clients into fully data driven enterprises. Understanding how AI is transforming Cyber defense, how automation is moving from 'screens' to outcomes and building the next generation of solutions where data and AI drive. The role was created specifically to ensure that data is not a single practice within Capgemini but becomes something systemic across our business, and the business of our clients.Part of the role includes how AI Trust will be defined and managed, ensuring that AI is executed in line with the business objectives, ethical concerns and regulatory constraints the organization requires.

The role was created specifically to ensure that data is not a single practice within Capgemini but becomes something systemic across our business, and the business of our clients.

Part of the role includes how AI Trust will be defined and managed, ensuring that AI is executed in line with the business objectives, ethical concerns and regulatory constraints the organization requires.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: With AI taking control of more business functions the challenge of trusting AI is increasing. My role is to work across our group, from people creating manufacturing robots and using AI in drug discovery, through to marketing communications to ensure that the AIs that are created are trusted. Trust means accountability of the AI, which means the team creating it ensures there is a clear owner, that its boundaries are clearly identified and the business, regulatory and ethical concerns are met.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: Responsible for Capgemini's North American Insights and Data business. The Insights and Data (I&D) practice is a full service global business line within Capgemini that covers the full information lifecycle from data ingestion and access, through management, governance and strategy to data science and advanced AI. My role as the leader of the North American practice is to deliver double digit growth and create an organisation capable of addressing some of the most complex information challenges in the market today. The team works across all sectors, outside of financial services, in North America and represents several thousand people working for our clients today.In a 12 month turn around focus I led the team to an over 20% absolute improvement in growth and reduced attrition by over 5%.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: Responsible for Capgemini's global AI Engineering division a team of over 3,000 engineers focused on creating the next generation Big Data platforms and industrialised approaches that enable business to much more quickly adopt AI technologies and concentrate on the value that they want to deliver.Capgemini's approach to AI Engineering is to focus on the standardisation and industrialisation of the major challenge of AI - getting the data in, ensure the data is correct and then ensuring the insight is delivered to the right end-point. This includes:- AI platform provisioning and management- Industrialized ingestion- DevOps and DevOps 4 Data- Migration to Big Data services- Automation of testing, reconciliation and other non-functional elements- Real-time eventing and integrationA core part of Capgemini's approach to AI engineering is the shift away from traditional BI delivery models towards new digital centric approaches based on business service architectures, microservices and automated through the use of Dev Ops. Helping customers not simply to transform their data landscape but also transform the way they deliver data projects.
positions.title: Global VP AI Engineering and Digital Delivery
positions.description_html:
Responsible for Capgemini's global AI Engineering division a team of over 3,000 engineers focused on creating the next generation Big Data platforms and industrialised approaches that enable business to much more quickly adopt AI technologies and concentrate on the value that they want to deliver.

Capgemini's approach to AI Engineering is to focus on the standardisation and industrialisation of the major challenge of AI - getting the data in, ensure the data is correct and then ensuring the insight is delivered to the right end-point. This includes:
- AI platform provisioning and management
- Industrialized ingestion
- DevOps and DevOps 4 Data
- Migration to Big Data services
- Automation of testing, reconciliation and other non-functional elements
- Real-time eventing and integration

A core part of Capgemini's approach to AI engineering is the shift away from traditional BI delivery models towards new digital centric approaches based on business service architectures, microservices and automated through the use of Dev Ops. Helping customers not simply to transform their data landscape but also transform the way they deliver data projects.

positions.subtitle: Capgemini
positions.description: Responsible for the leadership, transformation and management of Capgemini's Big Data business from multiple regional teams into a single global organisation that has more than tripled its sales rate in the first two years. Moving from regional teams to a global team covering all sectors and with over 2,000 dedicated Big Data specialists in the Americas, Europe, India and Asia Pacific the business has been a major pull-through of work for other areas of the firm by taking an "Industrialised First" approach to delivering Big Data programs.Key to the approach of both growing the business but also delivering continued and sustained client success has been the ability to leverage global perspectives for local business problems. This comes from having a unified approach to Big Data and Data Science solution architecture and providing proven and consistent ways of not just delivering analytical value but reducing operational costs over traditional data solutions.

positions.subtitle: Global Outsourcing, Capgemini
positions.description: Originally Head of SOA for Capgemini's Global Outsourcing division I took over the SaaS role as part of the Google partnership. Focus is on the strategic direction of SOA and SaaS for customers and outsourcers and how it can be used to align IT spend more closely to the business value it provides.During this time I defined the group approach towards the SaaS and Cloud markets and created the foundations for the group's transition towards these new technology areas. Working with Amazon, Salesforce.com on the cloud/SaaS area and traditional vendors such as Microsoft, Oracle, IBM and SAP on how their technologies could be licensed and supported in these new environments.Another key part of the role was the strategy for Application Outsourcing where I worked on how SOA, SaaS and other elements were changing Application Outsourcing and defined a new joined up approach between Application Run/Operations and Application Development. At the time the group had two separate divisions for Run and Development and this work provided a framework that enabled the two to be considered as a continuum. The group moved to a unified management structure a couple of years after this work completed.

publications.title: Sea Change - is your company prepared for the coming big data wave?
publications.subtitle: Teradata
publications.description: Every business leader knows that in today‚Äôs knowledge economy, it is essential to take control of information to make decisions with confidence. The challenge is to quickly identify what should be retained, avoid duplication where possible, and make use of the insights being generated.

publications.title: Mastering Big Data
publications.subtitle: Capgemini
publications.description: The amount of data being created by organizations is increasing exponentially every year and is not something that companies can opt out of. The challenge is therefore to quickly identify what should be retained, avoid duplication where possible, and make use of the information that is being generated. Big Data is not about acquiring data from outside of an organization; it‚Äôs about combining the Big Data being created internally with external Big Data sets.Big Data is, therefore, about being able to access and leverage much larger information sets than ever before in order to gain greater insight into markets and opportunities. At the heart of Big Data is the ability to ask questions about what will happen and receive more accurate answers than has been possible until now.

publications.title: Mastering Retail
publications.subtitle: Capgemini
publications.description: Retail is a competitive business and in the modern world the effective exploitation of information is a critical factor for business success. However, despite the fact that the retail sector pioneered the concept of mastering and controlling key pieces of business information, in many areas of the industry vital information remains beyond the control of the business.

publications.title: Building the Business Case for Master Data Management
publications.subtitle: Capgemini
publications.description: An effective business case for master data management (MDM) communicates the problem of fragmented and contradictory data in terms that are relevant to business decision-makers.Much like master data itself, an MDM business case is ideally complete, reliable and timely. This white paper outlines the key considerations that IT professionals should keep in mind when formulating an MDM business case.

publications.title: Mastering Social Media
publications.subtitle: Capgemini
publications.description: Social media is the current buzzword in marketing and IT, and generating a significant amount of both interest and hot-air. The reality is that social media does not represent a revolution in marketing or customer engagement but it does represent a significant evolution, and one that presents businesses with greater opportunities. In order to really leverage social media, organizations need to stop looking at it as a separate world and look at how the normal processes of customer identification and acquisition can be extended to incorporate the social world.Treating social media as another enterprise information asset and incorporating it into the overall enterprise information map will deliver the benefits expected from social media marketing but even more so, will enable the collaboration of physical, electronic and social marketing, and provide risk and servicing areas with better information on the customer and how they behave.

publications.title: Mastering the Information Ocean
publications.subtitle: Capgemini
publications.description: In the modern business, the volume of information is increasing and the value of that information is becoming ever more critical to the business‚Äôs success. The reality though is that over 80% of companies are relying on inaccurate management reports and that most organizations find themselves drowning in data. Although there are a large number of different challenges in turning data into information, there is one common element which drives problems in one third of customer service interactions, 30% of brokerage transactions and which drives up to $50bn in costs within the US retail supply chain alone ‚Äì poor Master Data Management.

publications.title: Enterprise SOA Adoption Strategies
publications.subtitle: InfoQ
publications.description: Major changes in technology have not been driven by the technologies themselves but by the change in thinking that they enabled. OO design changed software by changing thoughts away from procedures and onto real world "things". This book argues that for SOA to succeed we must move our thoughts away from the implementation technologies and towards the "what" of the business. Using a straight-forward, pictorially driven, methodology the book explains who to discover what the business services really are and how to construct an overall business service architecture. The book covers defining the Business Service Architecture, how to classify services for business value and delivery, understanding the role of IT in supporting the architecture, how project and portfolio management needs to change, how to use a Service Architecture to identify KPIs, and how and when to use Business Process in a service architecture.

publications.title: Toward an Acceptable Definition of Service
publications.subtitle: IEEE Software
publications.description: The methodologies such as extreme programming and the Rational Unified Process claim that they work with service-oriented architecture, but neither was designed with SOA in mind. Both predominately focuses on a project's delivery, not on the system's initial conceptualization. For service definition to succeed, there must be tooled support for the automatic flow of information among architects, designers, developers, maintainers, and, most importantly, the client. XML and Web service standards are helping architects improve the definition of service and provide a consistent framework for realizing service-oriented architecture's promises.

publications.title: Next Generation Airline Information: Using Consumer Devices to Keep Passengers Informed and as an Additional Channel to Market
publications.subtitle: IEEE
publications.description: The airline industries are going through a period of change and face many challenges to keep consumers loyal to their services and to offer differential services with low production cost. The rise of J2ME mobile phones presents an opportunity and a challenge to airline companies, the chance to increase information available to passengers to reduce dissatisfaction, and the challenge of how to produce applications for a wide variety of devices. It also enables companies to offer additional services via an application that is resident on the consumer?s own phone. Using the security and storage options available on J2ME devices, airlines, and other companies, can use mobile phones as a mechanism to enable "least resistance" selling. This paper details how one prototyping exercise demonstrated how J2ME mobile phones, both on the original MIDP 1.0 and the more advanced MIDP 2.0 offered a clear business and cost advantage to one UK based airline. Hopefully by the time this paper is read the prototypes will be functioning systems that are being used by consumers.

publications.title: Web Services and Java
publications.subtitle: IEEE
publications.description: Web Services are an established technology established under a new guise.

Leading Capgemini‚Äôs Applied Innovation Exchange in San Francisco, I help Fortune 500s turn disruption into advantage. Our focus is accelerating innovation through AI Agents, Robotics, and emerging tech that delivers measurable business outcomes. At the AIE, we bridge Silicon Valley‚Äôs startup edge with enterprise scale, co-creating with founders, technologists, and visionary leaders to drive transformation where it counts. Previously Global Head of Digital at Sogeti and CTO of Capgemini Scandinavia, I‚Äôve led teams that unlocked efficiency gains, tripled revenue, and reshaped customer experience. Let‚Äôs build what‚Äôs next.

The way he would put it "Its like playing in a Rock Band !" Ajay‚Äù

Amit Chintawar ‚ÄúAndreas is one of those rare people whose passion for technology is unparalleled but his compassion for people is also unmatched. recommendations: Malhar Purandare (Ph. D.) ‚ÄúDinesh and I met during one of the EM sessions in Pune, probably around 5-6 years back. From the first interaction, I found Dinesh's energy highly infectious. Over the years, we have conducted many EM sessions together and those were always the best experiences. What I like the most is his open way to mentor the participants effortlessly. To me, he is one of the best examples of people centric leader, who never shies away from helping others. From his vast pool of experiences in delivery, stakeholder management and financial management, he always picks up right examples to coach his team. He truly embodies Team Spirit and Fun, the two Capgemini values. I always look forward to working with him, since while working with him is the best enjoyment.‚Äù

Ambili Ramkumar ‚ÄúDinesh is a fine combination of democratic and a situational leadership. I have worked with him for a short duration on a super critical Product implementation program where he had to fly down almost every week for the first few months. He showed us how to stabilise critical situations, break down the issues to small chunks, invite in right support systems and showed us the way forward. Vince, and the teams he builds, create value for his clients by bringing his combination of: industry depth, ‚Äúon the ground‚Äù understanding of their business model and culture, with a relentless focus on delivery and client satisfaction. With more than 28 years of experience in leading, designing and constructing business transformation, technology modernization, and managed services programs, Vince has delivered business outcomes for his clients on a global scale, forming teams spanning the U.S, Europe, Asia, Australia, LATAM, and the Middle East, while working in various global markets within the Americas, Europe and Asia.

publications.title: Test Architecture Planning for Test Coverage and Efficiency
publications.subtitle: QAI QUEST
publications.description: Test coverage and efficiency go hand in hand and share a distinct relationship in directly impacting quality and cost respectively. There are number of popular test management tools in the market today, however, achieving optimal test coverage with minimal tests has become more challenging and the need for using the right tools and methods has become more significant than ever. Architecting tests in order to achieve the right test coverage involves robust test design, execution, management methods, and best practices. In this presentation, Shiva will discuss methodologies and best practices coupled with an objective metrics and risk based test model that can achieve test coverage without compromising cost or quality.

publications.title: Distributed eXtreme Programming (XP) Testing - An Agile Test Approach for Offshore Outsourcing
publications.subtitle: Asia Pacific Software Testing Conference
publications.description: One of the key principles behind XP testing and software development is effective communication and transparency between clients QA testers, software programmers, SME‚Äôs and the end users. If there is anything that has been emphasised repeatedly about agile methods, it is the need for real-time communication, preferably face-to-face. This physical proximity is one of the several reasons why agile techniques are so effective. But considering the factors of cost saving and faster time to market, the same approach cannot be taken for a large project or on a long term basis to gain business value. One of the viable solutions to address the above situation is the implementation of a ‚ÄúDistributed eXtreme Programming Testing‚Äù. This white paper explores the need of Distributed XP testing, provides a primer on key challenges of implementation and illustrates the approach of addressing the challenge. The white paper also discusses our experiences in performing Distributed XP testing and has also shown that at the end of day, we can stay true to the values and principles of XP and not compromising the practices in a distributed environment. A Distributed testing teams actively collaborate on a common software/ systems project separated by Distance, Time zone, Culture. In Distributed XP testing model, the team members are physically apart bringing in a relaxation to the XP principle. The team can be distributed across various geographical locations and offshore centres. The offshore team in conjunction with ‚Äúvirtual‚Äù team (again at offshore) bridge the distance and bring in XP practices to Distributed testing

publications.title: Software Testing Do's and Dont's
publications.subtitle: Stickyminds.com
publications.description: In software testing, one has to go beyond the boundaries to explore the existence of not yet discovered errors. This article will discuss testing dos and don‚Äôts and give a few tips for successful testing

publications.title: A Handbook for Load Testing
publications.subtitle: Stickyminds
publications.description: Load testing is evolving as a discipline and it has discovered most of its business in the Internet economy. This paper examines various types of load testing and provides a detailed discussion on the load testing process. All load testing tools simulate realistic volumes of users to measure, define, validate, and maintain optimal application performance. There are many tools available on the market that can help in load testing, but this paper presents a brief overview of Web Application Stress Tool (WAST) that can serve the purpose

publications.title: An Effective Handbook for Implementing Test Strategies
publications.subtitle: Stickyminds
publications.description: This article aims at establishing a test strategy because the development of a test strategy is a means of communication with the customer on the organization of testing. Moreover this article talks about why we need a test strategy and what happens if there are no test strategies. Finally, a test strategy will keep the customers aware of the extent to which the testing would be done thereby avoiding risks later.

detailed_profile.about: Genevieve is a seasoned executive (14+ years) specializing in innovation consulting and partnership strategy. Teaming up with partners and startups, she translates the latest, bleeding-edge technologies into solutions that create new captivating customer experiences, intelligent operations and automated processes. She specializes in: - Global partnership strategy and management - Go-to-market and growth strategy - Industry vertical solution build - Pilot definition and management - Emerging technology and start-up curation Subject matter knowledge includes: smart store experiences; Artificial Intelligence (AI) / Machine Learning (ML) applied to discrete industries; sustainability; Internet Of Things (IoT) use cases (e.g., asset tracking, smart products, connected logistics) across industries ; Product Lifecycle Management (PLM); market acceleration and penetration; technology adoption and change management Genevieve has worked in Europe, Canada and the US assisting leading multinational across industries, with a primary focus in Retail and Consumer Products.

recommendations: Jackie Johanson ‚ÄúFirst things first, Johnny is a wonderful team member. He's so invested in his work yet makes the effort to keep up personal connections and bring light-hearted banter to everyday interactions‚Äìwhich I really appreciate. Johnny is a thoughtful collaborator and excels at combining the strengths of others, together with his own to deliver impactful content campaigns. When Johnny is tackling an unfamiliar subject matter (which is common in the world of technology innovation) he is quick to research and learn the topic, helping him to steer content creators, subject matter experts, and creative teams to produce accurate & compelling content that hit on the marketing strategy. Johnny is a master multi-tasker and genius prioritizer. You won't catch him off guard or unorganized. He's a reliable communicator and keeps everyone around him on top of their game.‚Äù

Gail Gordon ‚ÄúI had the pleasure of working with Johnny while in Enterprise IT at Boeing. We focused on our internal customers and communication for the organization. Johnny is a motivated self-starter and accomplishes all his projects on time and with quality. He is tenacious, a diplomatic team player and a dedicated team member. His work ethic and concern for the customer experience are beyond measure. He always takes the customer into consideration in everything he does. When working customer requests Johnny always replied within a timely manner. He would either have an answer, research the topic or contact one of our subject matter experts. Johnny quickly became a person to go to for technical answers and knowing who to point the customer to. He also put together self-help videos and a monthly newsletter with articles focused on areas of customer interest. In doing so, he collaborated with the team to provide simplified directions on a broad range of topics (mobile devices and computers) on our website for those customers who needed clarity on the technical speak. In working with Johnny, I have learned from his insights and we were able to share ideas and strategies. Johnny will be a valuable asset to any organization and has a passion for working with a technical consumer-facing product or service. ‚Äù

recommendations: MAGGIE NATION ‚ÄúThere are executive recruiters and there are talent whisperers. Christine Stack belongs in that latter rarefied group. I've probably worked with 30+ recruiters over my career. Some were 3rd-party hired hands, others worked internally. Some had amazing follow-up skills, others ghosted me. From the minute that Christine reached out to me on LI, I knew she was would be different. And she was. Engaging, informed, candid and wonderfully authentic ‚Äì Christine made it clear that she would be as much my champion as she was the brand she represented, Capgemini Invent. She was frank ‚Äì even brutally honest ‚Äì about the opportunity and what it would take to thrive in that role. Christine has become the yardstick by which I'll measure every other recruiter by. If she reaches out to you, be sure to respond ‚Äì you won't regret it.‚Äù

Aditi Kejriwal ‚ÄúChristine is one of the best Exec Recruiters I've come across so far. She recently helped me with hiring one of the VPs in our HR & Workforce Experience Consulting practice and it was an excellent experience. I was thoroughly impressed with Christine's listening skills and compassion for the Candidate as well as me. She was very professional, laid out the process very clearly and made sure the right rigor and discipline was injected through the process. She maintained honest and regular communication with the candidate too, and got excellent feedback from the candidate. Christine is a real asset for Capgemini and I look forward to our continued cooperation, as we build the Workforce & Organization practice together.‚Äù

detailed_profile.about: As a Director at the Capgemini Research Institute, our in-house think tank on all things digital, I work closely with industry leaders and academics to help large organizations understand the nature and impact of digital disruption. Prior to my current role, I worked in Capgemini Invent's Digital Strategy practice. I have research and consulting experience in digital transformation, strategy, operations, and customer experience across multiple industries including automotive, consumer goods, financial services, higher education, life sciences, professional services, and retail.

publications.title: Organization Implications From Scaling Digital
publications.subtitle: Society for Maintenance and Reliability Professionals
publications.description: "Considering organizational implications before scaling digital technologies increases the likelihood of success. Digital is becoming more than just a buzz word in maintenance and reliability activities with the newest wave of Industry 4.0 technologies ‚Äì e.g. artificial intelligence, internet of things, cloud computing, etc. Many companies in asset intensive industries have been testing new technologies and are starting to scale across asset types and sites to improve capital efficiency, safety and productivity. Organizational considerations for scaling digital include user-focused work process changes, effective remote monitoring and alerting selection, balancing site versus center staffing and helping key staff transition to becoming knowledgeable workers."

experience.title: Webinar Services Technician
experience.description: BrightTALK is a B2B marketing company that hosts webinars for businesses to connect to their current and prospective clients. My role as technical director is to ensure the audio and visual components run smoothly and to communicate to the clients before and throughout the event . Like live TV, I ensure the right cameras are spotlighted at the right moment, that the right branding graphics are added when referenced and that slides for presentations are displayed when needed. It is also an important aspect of my role to lead technical rehearsals prior to the event to ensure all the presenters and stakeholders feel supported and prepared.

experience.title: Head of Musical Theatre and Acrobatics
experience.description: The Acrobatics class started as 3 kids and within those 3 years built to 70 students divided into a four tiered level system that I had devised on my own. I wrote my own curriculum and benchmarks that were then used to guide assistant teachers and new hires. Musical Theatre also grew to a size that meant we needed to take on a new teacher and it was my responsibility to ensure the end of year 10 minute musical was ready for the stage by end of year. recommendations: David Rubin ‚ÄúI had the privilege to work with Andy during a large Salesforce implementation project. Andy was tasked with integrating 8 business units, all with varying SFDC experience, into a single enterprise instance. He simultaneously created standardized sales processes, key reporting analytics and an application governance model. My particular business unit had the most sophisticated implementation of SFDC, hence we were the BU most impacted during the integration. As such, Andy was sensitive to our needs and collaborated to ensure our requirements and best practice recommendations influenced the final design of the new org. I learned a lot from Andy, and many of his lessons prompted me to pursue my career in technology consulting. I would recommend Andy for any position where leadership, organization, and business process best practice guidance are paramount. Thank you Andy.‚Äù

Bernie Daina ‚ÄúAs a member of the founding management team responsible for personnel recruitment, selection and a variety of human-resources processes, I worked closely with Andy Forbes for almost two years at the web 2.0 startup for collectors, WorthPoint. Andy initiated and managed our IT and Development, including full-time domestic employees and outsourced, offshore IT and Engineering capabilities. His work was timely, effective, and reliable. He is a consummate team player, one who brings extraordinary energy, commitment, and know-how to an emerging-growth technology company. He is constructive, flexible, and tireless. Without Andy, our company would have suffered countless, potentially crippling glitches and delays. He knows startups inside out, and can consult on, or manage, the complexity involved in launching a new enterprise with a cheerful outlook and a can-do attitude. Great person!‚Äù

publications.title: ChatGPT for Accelerating Salesforce Development: Achieve faster, smarter, and more cost-effective Salesforce Delivery with ChatGPT
publications.subtitle: Packt
publications.description: ChatGPT for Salesforce Development is an indispensable guide for Salesforce business analysts, developers, testers, and product owners seeking to integrate ChatGPT into their workflow. This book delves into the intricacies of Salesforce design, configuration, coding, and testing, demonstrating how ChatGPT can simplify complex setups and enhance project team efficiency.With this book, you‚Äôll unlock the effective use of ChatGPT for crafting user stories that align seamlessly with project goals, learn how to design and implement Salesforce flows, and quickly write clear, comprehensive, and high-quality project documentation. As you advance, you‚Äôll leverage ChatGPT to write new Apex code, decipher existing code, and explore the development of web services and callouts. This book spans trigger creation and the development of Lightning Web Components (LWC), highlighting how these can accelerate the development process. Applying ChatGPT's debugging capabilities, you‚Äôll swiftly identify and resolve Salesforce issues to uphold the integrity and performance of your Salesforce applications.By the end of this book, you‚Äôll be adept at integrating ChatGPT at every stage of Salesforce project delivery, from initial configuration to final testing.

detailed_profile.name: Michael Lehman
detailed_profile.about: I‚Äôm a curious guy who‚Äôs still exploring and creating. I had decided at a fairly young age that I was going to work with computers ‚Äúwhen I grew up‚Äù, and so I did. Started programming at 12, spent many late nights at friend‚Äôs house over my teenage years learning operating systems, web pages, and the networking basics. We even started our own corporation at 18 (I was CEO! Unfortunately I had no idea how to run a business, but we gave it a good go!) I moved over to the outsourcing world at 20, and have had an amazing adventure supporting all things infrastructure for Fortune 500 companies ever since (with a focus on Wintel, VMware, and Automation) While my job has never said ‚Äúdeveloper‚Äù, I‚Äôve coded and automated in various languages and toolsets the whole way, and absolutely love the creative problem solving it allows. Learning how to ‚Äúshift left‚Äù, do continuous pipelines, perform configuration management, compliance testing, and reporting, containerize, orchestrate, and all the other tasks that make our work lives that much better and our customers effective has been amazing. Each day is a new challenge, and an opportunity to learn ‚Äì and I‚Äôm excited for the possibilities we‚Äôre going to explore together.

recommendations: Jeff Bradley ‚ÄúLuisa interned with our team for six months, taking on new tool development, bug fixes and worked with other teams on the cleanup of technical debt. Her honesty and openness, coupled with technical skills, immediately made her a successful member of our team. If she didn't know something, she said so and was eager to learn from others. She was also good at saying when she wanted to dig in, because she felt there was progress she could make on her own. On her second day of the internship, she already had a pull request fixing a bug in our Python tools. She continued to implement fixes and adding new tools. Once she was familiar with our tools, Luisa identified and drove new improvements in our development environment. One of her major projects addressed the technical debt of compiler warnings that have crept into our C++ codebase. Luisa jumped in and quickly made an impact, working with technical leads from across the R&D department on code reviews and discussing approaches for the complex code needs. Luisa's a quick and eager learner, who made working with her easy and fun.‚Äù

Brent Villalobos ‚ÄúLuisa interned on my team. She helped my team write configuration tools and helped clean up many of our compiler warnings in our legacy codebase. She's hard-working and resourceful. She can dive into projects, learn quickly and independently, and be productive in a short period of time. She would be a valuable asset to any organization.‚Äù

recommendations: Jackie Johanson ‚ÄúWorking with Jeff Hebert over the years has been one of the great privileges of my career. He‚Äôs not just an exceptional leader‚Äîhe‚Äôs the kind of person who brings clarity, focus, and energy to everything he touches. Jeff has a remarkable ability to cut through the noise, simplify complex goals, and get people aligned and moving in the right direction. Whether we were navigating acquisitions, shifting market dynamics, or just the everyday challenges of growth, Jeff always led with a calm confidence, strategic precision, and an unwavering commitment to both performance and people. What I admire most is how he balances ambition with authenticity. Jeff leads with transparency and integrity. He knows how to rally teams around a vision, ask the right questions, and make tough calls without losing site of the human impact. He builds strong cultures and earns trust quickly (and keeps it) because he lives the values‚Äìnot just talks about them. Jeff is the kind of superhuman leader who makes you better just by working with him. I learned a lot from him‚Äîand had a lot of fun along the way. Any team would be lucky to have him.‚Äù

Redwood Stephens ‚ÄúJeff leads a team of over 100 multidisciplinary hardware product development experts at Synapse. He leads by example, personally spearheading development of sophisticated people and process tools we rely on to manage the business. I feel incredibly fortunate to have Jeff on the team because he is conscientious, has strong critical thinking skills, and is motivated to improve all aspects of the business. ‚Äù

patents.title: Footwear Having Sensor System
patents.description: An article of footwear includes an upper member and a sole structure, with a sensor system connected to the sole structure. The sensor system includes a plurality of sensors that are configured for detecting forces exerted by a user's foot on the sensor. The sensor system also includes a port that is configured to receive a module to place the module in communication with the sensors. The port includes a housing with a chamber configured to receive the module and an interface engaged with the housing and having at least one electrical contact exposed to the chamber. Additional retaining structure and interface structure may be included.

recommendations: Grace Park ‚ÄúI have gotten to know Nafiri over the last year while working on an engagement together. She is a strong leader with outstanding presence, strong communication skills, and the ability to analyze and make impactful decisions. She is well respected across various teams, and I have admired and learned from her leadership skills. This was why I jumped at the opportunity to be coached by her. For 3 months, Nafiri coached me for personal and professional development. She maintained the perfect balance of knowing when to facilitate and nudge me to a right direction or letting me lead to find the right direction myself. She ties in assessments, theories, and definitions she has learned throughout her trainings to applicable examples and coaching areas. She has shown her commitment by texting me reminders of action items I set for myself, asking how she can be helpful offline, and sending me resources relevant to our discussion. Throughout this duration, it reminded me that Nafiri is coaching me to form a solid approach of identifying conflict, forming a method of resolution, and planning the action. She is teaching skills and not solutions to prepare me for a self-sustaining methodology to resolve conflicts in the future. I feel better equipped to be confident in my personal and professional journey, and I attribute it greatly to her.‚Äù

Anuradha Sinha ‚ÄúPassionate, enthusiast, talented, charming and ever approachable, those are only few words to describe her, but she is so much more than that. I was really lucky to get the chance to work along with Nafiri and it was a great learning experience for me. She is always very helpful and have really strong knowledge about her domain and work. I have always find her approach very professional and systematic but she also brings out-of-box thinking to regular orthodox work. I wish her all the success for future and wish I would get chance to work with her again.‚Äù
